subject: polity
title: Fundamental Rights vs Directive Principles - Comprehensive Comparison

rows.fundamentalRights: **Part III** (Articles 12-35)
rows.dpsp: **Part IV** (Articles 36-51)

rows.fundamentalRights: **Negative obligations** - State shall **NOT** do certain things (e.g., shall not discriminate - Art 15)
rows.dpsp: **Positive obligations** - State **SHALL** do certain things (e.g., shall strive to promote welfare - Art 38)

rows.fundamentalRights: **Justiciable** - Can be enforced through courts; Violation can be challenged
rows.dpsp: **Non-justiciable** (Art 37) - Cannot be enforced through courts; State cannot be compelled to implement

rows.fundamentalRights: **Enforceable by law** - Courts can issue writs (Art 32, 226); Violation leads to legal consequences
rows.dpsp: **Not enforceable** - Only moral obligation on State; No legal remedy for non-implementation

rows.fundamentalRights: **Individual rights and liberty** - Protect individual against State tyranny
rows.dpsp: **Social and economic democracy** - Establish welfare state; Socio-economic justice

rows.fundamentalRights: **Liberal individualism** - Based on Western concept of individual liberty
rows.dpsp: **Socialism and welfare** - Based on socialist principles; Common good over individual

rows.fundamentalRights: **Individual-centric** - Rights of individual citizens
rows.dpsp: **Society-centric** - Welfare of society as a whole

rows.fundamentalRights: **Against State only** (Art 12 defines 'State'); Exceptions: Art 17, 23-24 also against private individuals
rows.dpsp: **Directives to State** - Guidelines for State in making laws and policies

rows.fundamentalRights: **Limitations on State power** - 'Thou shalt not' (State cannot violate)
rows.dpsp: **Guidelines for State action** - 'Thou shalt' (State should implement)

rows.fundamentalRights: **Means to an end** - FRs are the means
rows.dpsp: **End goals** - DPSPs are the ends (Granville Austin)

rows.fundamentalRights: **All persons** (some only for citizens - Art 15, 16, 19, 29, 30)
rows.dpsp: **Entire society** - Aimed at welfare of all

rows.fundamentalRights: **Difficult to amend** - Part of Basic Structure (Kesavananda Bharati); Core FRs cannot be amended
rows.dpsp: **Easier to amend** - Can be amended more easily; Not part of basic structure (except some aspects)

rows.fundamentalRights: Borrowed from **USA** (Bill of Rights concept)
rows.dpsp: Borrowed from **Ireland** (Irish Constitution 1937)

rows.fundamentalRights: **Includes political rights** - Right to vote, contest elections (Art 326), freedom of expression (Art 19(1)(a))
rows.dpsp: **No political rights** - Focuses on socio-economic rights only

rows.fundamentalRights: **Limited economic rights** - Right to property removed from FRs (44th Amendment 1978); Now legal right (Art 300A)
rows.dpsp: **Strong economic focus** - Economic justice, livelihood, equal pay (Art 39), living wage (Art 43)

rows.fundamentalRights: **Some social rights** - Equality (Art 14-18), abolition of untouchability (Art 17), minorities (Art 29-30)
rows.dpsp: **Comprehensive social rights** - Social justice (Art 38), welfare (Art 39), education (Art 41), maternity (Art 42)

rows.fundamentalRights: **Immediate implementation** - Effective from commencement of Constitution (Jan 26, 1950)
rows.dpsp: **Gradual implementation** - Subject to economic capacity; Implemented through legislation over time

rows.fundamentalRights: **Supreme** - Any law violating FRs is void (Art 13); Courts can strike down laws
rows.dpsp: **Subordinate to FRs** - If conflict, FRs generally prevail (State of Madras v Champakam 1951); But balanced approach (Minerva Mills 1980)

rows.fundamentalRights: **Constitutional remedies** - Art 32 (SC), Art 226 (HC); 5 writs available
rows.dpsp: **No remedies** - Cannot move court for enforcement; Only legislative/executive action

rows.fundamentalRights: **Can be suspended** - Art 358 (Art 19 suspended automatically); Art 359 (other FRs by Presidential order); Art 20-21 cannot be suspended (44th Amendment)
rows.dpsp: **Cannot be suspended** - Remain in force; State expected to continue implementation

rows.fundamentalRights: **Active role** - Courts enforce FRs; Judicial review; Writs; PIL
rows.dpsp: **Interpretive role** - Courts use DPSPs to interpret FRs and laws; Cannot compel implementation

rows.fundamentalRights: **Subject to restrictions** - Art 19(2)-(6) allows reasonable restrictions; Can be limited for public interest
rows.dpsp: **No limitations** - But implementation subject to economic capacity and resources

rows.fundamentalRights: **Self-executing** - No legislation needed for enforcement; Automatically enforceable
rows.dpsp: **Need legislation** - Require laws/schemes for implementation (e.g., MGNREGA for Art 41, RTE for Art 45→21A)

rows.fundamentalRights: Called Art 32 (Remedies) **'Heart and Soul of Constitution'** - Without remedies, FRs meaningless
rows.dpsp: Called DPSPs **'Novel feature'** of Constitution - Unique to Indian Constitution; Non-justiciable yet fundamental

rows.fundamentalRights:
• Equality before law (Art 14)
• Freedom of speech (Art 19(1)(a))
• Right to life (Art 21)
• Right to education (Art 21A)
• Constitutional remedies (Art 32)
rows.dpsp:
• Welfare state (Art 38)
• Livelihood, equal pay (Art 39)
• Right to work (Art 41)
• Living wage (Art 43)
• Uniform Civil Code (Art 44)
• Environment (Art 48A)

complementaryNature: **FRs and DPSPs are complementary** - Not contradictory
**Granville Austin**: 'FRs are means; DPSPs are ends'
**Both aim**: Establish socio-economic democracy in India
judicialView: **State of Madras v Champakam (1951)**: FRs prevail over DPSPs in case of conflict
**Kesavananda Bharati (1973)**: FRs and DPSPs together form basic structure; Neither absolute supremacy
**Minerva Mills (1980)**: Balance between FRs and DPSPs; Harmony needed; Indian Constitution has two lungs - FRs and DPSPs
**Unnikrishnan (1993)**: Courts must harmonize FRs and DPSPs; Both are integral
**Modern approach**: Courts use DPSPs to expand scope of FRs (Art 21 expansion includes DPSP goals)
constitutionalProvisions: **Art 31C** (25th Amendment 1971): Laws implementing Art 39(b), (c) given primacy over Art 14, 19 (socialist DPSPs)
**Art 31A, 31B**: Land reform laws protected from FR challenges
These provisions show **Legislature tried to give priority to DPSPs** in certain cases
gradualTransformation: **DPSP → FR**: Art 45 (free education) became Art 21A (FR) via 86th Amendment 2002
**Judicial expansion**: Courts expanded Art 21 (Life) to include DPSP goals:
Shows **convergence of FRs and DPSPs** over time
examTips: **Remember**: FRs = Justiciable, Negative, Individual, Enforceable, Means
**Remember**: DPSPs = Non-justiciable, Positive, Social, Non-enforceable, Ends
**Key cases**: Champakam (FR prevails), Minerva Mills (balance), Kesavananda (basic structure)
**Granville Austin quote**: Very important - 'FRs are means; DPSPs are ends'
**Novel feature**: DPSPs are novel - non-justiciable yet fundamental in governance
**Borrowed from**: FRs from USA; DPSPs from Ireland
**Complementary not contradictory**: Together form conscience of Constitution

data.summary: **FRs vs DPSPs**: FRs (Part III, Art 12-35) are **justiciable, negative, individual-centric, enforceable** rights borrowed from USA. DPSPs (Part IV, Art 36-51) are **non-justiciable, positive, society-centric, non-enforceable** directives borrowed from Ireland. **FRs = Means, DPSPs = Ends** (Granville Austin). In conflict, **FRs generally prevail** (Champakam 1951), but **balanced approach** needed (Minerva Mills 1980). Both form **Basic Structure** and are **complementary** - together establish socio-economic democracy. Modern trend: **DPSP goals incorporated into FRs** through Art 21 expansion (livelihood, health, education, environment). **25+ points of distinction** for comprehensive exam answer.
